Granted I've been aware of this from day one, but I'm glad for it. And now that I've beaten around the bush, here's what I'm trying to get at; I don't want to be responsible for anyone on this trip. I don't think I could live with the burden of wrecking someone else's ride just because I don't have everything mapped out. yes, he confirmed, this refers to me -- my ride. he continues: You know, I think I've made this point elsewhere in this blog, but I don't care. I'll not deal with lost luggage or bad accommodations. (ah, yes, maybe i should make a recommendation... maybe when you embark on all subsequent adventures/relationshipsyou shouldprovide a handout -- a brochure, if you will. something that highlights the impending loss of luggage, the inadequate accommodations... hell, if i had gotten one, i would've at least packed light.) he wraps it all up (and quite poignantly, at that) with: I don't want to compromise myself . while i could go on and on and on about this little phrase and the egotistical connotes attached whichveil cold feet, i won't. and perhaps this has and always will be one of my shortcomings. it is sufficient for me to simply walk away. they say old dogs can't, after all, be taught new tricks. but i digress. so, we wrap up this conversation that we're having... and he asks if we are cool. "are we cool?" as simple andplainas that. now again, remember my shortcomings... will he ever really know just how much he's hurt me? probably not. will i ever tell him? lash out with rage and disparaging remarks? it's not in me, remember? does he need to know thathe'sseduced me withsix years worth of words? no, he knows that already. does he need to knowhe's beenmy crutch -- the calm voice i hear in my head when my ownis panicked?no,i assume he's figured that one out too. i'm justnot that variety of girl who needs to lay on the guilt to appease her own demons. i sometimes think that maybe i need to be. especially when it seems he skips out with just his handcarry. butdespite all this, i feel compelled to extend a semi-apology -- because, as he says,he does not have "everything mapped out"and i thinkhe thought that i expected him to. this was never my intent and i never expectedhim to have answers to questions that had notyet been formed. and so, i offer up a truce (along with the truth), that if everI hadany expectations, they were onlythese: one -- that every word out of your mouth and penned by your handbe spoken in truth andtwo -- thatif you loved me,you'd not give up on me before we got our chance

i need a change; i've outgrown seattle. well, maybe that's a bit much. maybe it's more that seams are being stretched than anything else. seams that are very dangerously close to bursting open. maybe it's that i am now kicking myself in the ass for not going on that interview. if i could up and leave and make a change, a real change, here is what i'd do: i'd sell my car, i'd use that money to pay off my bills, i'd put my college loan in deferment, sell everything i own and mail home (guam home) anything of real value that i might want again someday (i.e., books, pictures and maybe a vibe). then i'd buy a ticket to somewhere where they don't speak english, where i'd need a calculator to figure out the exchange rate and where i don't know a single soul (okay, one person would be okay, but definitely not more than two). i'd learn their language, eat their food, love their men and then just before the seams started to stretch again, i'd pick a border (or ocean) and cross it. it just seems so perfect. i don't know where i'd start. maybe in spain or greece. or london. maybe morocco or even india. or thailand or japan. or even somewhere in the pacific. it just seems too perfect. if you could change your life tomorrow, what would you do?
